intro: Loranthus ferruginiflorus var. linearifolius, commonly known as the iron-flowered mistletoe, is a hemiparasitic plant that attaches to host trees through its haustoria to extract water and nutrients. It is native to parts of Africa and is characterized by its linear, lance-shaped leaves that are often clustered at the base of the stems. The plant produces small, clustered flowers that are typically reddish or orange in color, which attract pollinators such as bees and flies. Its fruits are small, fleshy berries that contain seeds dispersed by birds. This species plays an important ecological role in its native habitat, contributing to the biodiversity of forest ecosystems.
